description: From Middle English alwayes, allwayes, allweyes, a variant of Middle English allwaye, alwey, alle wey (“always”), from Old English ealneġ, ealneweġ (“always, perpetually”, literally “all the way, all the while, continuously”), from ealne + weġ (accusative case), equivalent to alway +‎ -s. Cognate with Scots alwayis (“always”), Low German allerwegens (“very often”, literally “all ways'”). More at all, way.

entries.meaning: At all times; throughout all time; since the beginning.
examples: Green has always been my favorite color. I’ve loved it for as long as I can remember.
Airplanes did not always exist as a form of transportation.
Synonyms: perpetually, continually, all the time, every time; see also Thesaurus:forever
Antonyms: at no time, never; see also Thesaurus:never

entries.meaning: Constantly during a certain period, or regularly at stated intervals (opposed to sometimes or occasionally).
examples: Synonyms: invariably, uniformly; see also Thesaurus:uniformly
Antonyms: manywise, sundrily, variously; see also Thesaurus:diversely
In this street, the shops always close during lunchtime.
I thought I could always go back to work.
Synonyms: anyhow, anyway, at any rate, regardless; see also Thesaurus:regardless
